column1: Whole Person Physiome Table for Endocrine System

List physiological functions as a hierarchy, starting with the body system in Function/1 (this should be the same as the table name), a major life function in Function/2, and more specific functions in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. Place limited explanatory text if needed in Function/Notes. Each function should include a ID from Gene Ontology (GO) if possible or another standard ontology. The LABEL column is the label for that ID as it appears in that ontology.
column26: Provide a very brief description (a few words) of the specific processes that occur during the corresponding function (e.g., a chemical reaction, physical change, feedback loop, etc.).
column31: Indicate the time scale category for this process: milliseconds, seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, years.
column32: List anatomical structures involved in the physiological function as a hierarchy, starting with an organ in Structure/1, part of an organ in Structure/2, and smaller sub-parts in subsequent columns. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use UBERON if possible or FMA as an alternative ontology.
column56: OPTIONAL: Cell (with ID if possible) to specify certain tissues or cell types within the anatomical structure
column62: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List clinical measures, such as laboratory tests, vital signs, or radiology studies, related to the physiological function. These columns are simple lists and are NOT hierarchical. Include an ID for the measurement, such as a LOINC code, if known. Add more columns if needed.
column74: OPTIONAL FOR NOW. List other interacting physiological functions. These columns are simple lists and NOT hierarchical. Add more columns if needed. For the LABEL and ID columns, use Gene Ontology (GO) if possible.
column86: DO NOT FILL THIS OUT YET. These columns will list body states or conditions that change the physiological process. (e.g., "fed", "fasted")
column88: DO NOT FILL THIS OUT YET. These columns will indicate the changes that occur during the corresponding body states. (e.g., "increase", "decrease")
column90: REQUIRED. Enter references in support of the information on this row. The ID column should include a standard identifier, such as a DOI or ISBN. The optional CHAPTER column should be used to list the relevant chapters in a book. The optional NOTES column can be used to clarify which part of the row the reference is for, such as a reference about the anatomical structures involved in the function rather than the interactions. Add more sets of reference columns if needed, making sure to include the ID column.

column26: glucagon increases glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis in the liver to increase blood glucose; acts via adrenergic signaling
column28: IF plasma glucose IS LOW -> INCREASE glucagon secretion
column29: IF plasma glucose IS HIGH -> DECREASE glucagon secretion

column28: IF plasma insulin IS LOW -> INCREASE glucagon secretion
column29: IF plasma insulin IS HIGH -> DECREASE glucagon secretion

column28: IF glucagon IS LOW -> (STATE = fed)
column29: IF glucagon IS HIGH -> (STATE = fasted)

column26: insulin promotes glycogen storage and glucose uptake; receptor tyrosin kinase; promotes translocation of GLUT4 in skeletal muscle and adipocytes
column28: IF plasma glucose IS LOW -> DECREASE insulin secretion
column29: IF plasma glucose IS HIGH -> INCREASE insulin secretion

column28: IF plasma glucose IS LOW -> (STATE = fasted)
column29: IF plasma glucose IS LOW -> (STATE = fed)

column28: IF plasma insulin IS LOW -> DECREASE membrane localized GLUT4
column29: IF plasma insulin IS HIGH -> INCREASE membrane localized GLUT4

IF pancreatic polypeptide IS HIGH -> DECREASE pancreatic enzyme secretion

column26: suprachiasmatic nucleus serves as the body's master clock regulator
SCN neurons integrate environmental light cues to synchronize circadian rhythm
melatonin promotes sleep and is secreted according to light/dark cycles
glucose sensing neurons in the hypothalamus regulate feeding and satiety
osmoreceptors in the hypothalamus regulate thirst and vasopressin release
thyroid epithelial cells produce T4; TPO oxidizes iodide to iodine, then attaches it to tyrosine residues on thyroglobulin to create MIT and DIT; two DIT molecules constitute T4
calcitonin lowers serum calcium by inhibiting bone resorption
column28: IF calcitonin IS HIGH -> DECREASE plasma calcium
column29: IF calcitonin IS HIGH -> DECREASE bone resorption

column26: deiodination of T4 generates T3, the active form of thyroid hormone (20% in thyroid)
deiodination of T4 generates T3, the active form of thyroid hormone (80% in peripheral tissues)
thyroglobulin is stored in colloid
